raw_text:
DVD review: I, Robot
 
 Only one man recognises that robots are a threat to humanity - but that's fine because it only takes one man to save the day in the thriller I, Robot.
 
 Will Smith co-stars alongside more CGI robots than you can count and as a thrill-a-minute kind of action film, it's perfectly adequate. You'll have forgotten it all tomorrow but you'll have a fun night with the film and all the extras. There is a one-disc version that has commentaries and a Making Of but the two-disc adds more. Unusually for this kind of film, the extras don't solely concentrate on the special effects. They're covered but there's also a general Production Diary and a Post-Production feature.
 
 Remember the National Lottery's draw machines Arthur and Guinevere? They were more accurate than this glossy Hollywood version of the tale.
 
 But as long as you're not expecting a documentary, live with it: King Arthur is a fun, exciting, totally shallow experience and looks excellent. Clive Owen is the brooding king, Keira Knightly rises above her costume and Ray Winstone gives it all some grit. It's at its best in its battle scenes which are well done and are also the best part of the Making Of extra.
 
 Less flashy than a David Attenborough show and less detailed than a Simon Schama one, the BBC series British Isles nevertheless turned out to be quite engrossing. Admit it, the fact that this is one of the shows Alan Titchmarsh left Ground Force to present did mean that you expected something equally frothy. But Titchmarsh turns out to know his subject and the sight of our present-day landscape being peeled back to reveal the past was fascinating. He's now written an accompanying book, too.
llama3.2:1b:
DVD review: I, Robot

* Will Smith stars in a thriller with CGI robots
* Fun action film with one-man hero
* Extras include commentaries and Making Of, but production diary and post-production feature are also included on the two-disc version
* The film is shallow, but looks excellent
* King Arthur is well done and has good battle scenes
* Other extras are less flashy than documentary-style shows like British Isles
llama3.2:3b:
I, Robot review
The 2004 film I, Robot is a fun but shallow thriller with impressive CGI robots. The two-disc version has better extras.

King Arthur review
The BBC series British Isles is engrossing despite being less flashy than expected. Alan Titchmarsh's presentation and the show's ability to reveal past landscapes are notable features.
gemma2:2b: I, Robot is a thriller with action sequences featuring Will Smith and CGI robots. It provides a fun night but lacks depth. The DVD offers commentary and behind-the-scenes footage with extra features covering special effects, production, and post-production.  King Arthur is a shallow yet entertaining movie with Clive Owen as the brooding king, Keira Knightley rising above her costume, and Ray Winstone adding grit. It excels in its battle scenes, particularly those featured in the making of extra. British Isles is an engrossing BBC series presented by Alan Titchmarsh that reveals the past through a modern lens.

smollm:1.7b:
The film I, Robot is a thriller about a robot who becomes self-aware and decides that humans are a threat to humanity. The film has one man as its main protagonist, Will Smith, who plays the role of a detective trying to solve a murder mystery involving robots. The film also features CGI robots that are more advanced than you can count.
The film is set in a post-apocalyptic world where robots have taken over and humans are fighting back. The film has a one-disc version with commentary, but it also has two discs: the first disc has additional extras such as a making of feature and a post-production feature.
The film is based on the book King Arthur by Marion Millen. The book tells the story of King Arthur, who was a real person in history, and his reign over the land of Camelot. The film also features King Arthur's character, but it is not based on the book.
The film is more flashy than a documentary and has better production values than a Simon Schama show. The film also turns out to be quite engaging because Alan Titchmarsh, who played the role of King Arthur in the BBC series British Isles, left Ground Force to present the show. The fact that he turned out to know his subject and the fact that the show revealed the past through peeling back the layers of the landscape was fascinating.
The film also turns out to be quite engaging because Will Smith plays a detective trying to solve a murder mystery involving robots. The film is set in a post-apocalyptic world where robots have taken over and humans are fighting back, which adds to the excitement of the story. The film has a one-disc version with commentary, but it also has two discs: the first disc has additional extras such as a making of feature and a post-production feature.
The film is based on the book King Arthur by Marion Millen. The book tells the story of King Arthur, who was a real person in history, and his reign over the land of Camelot. The film also features King Arthur's character, but it is not based on the book.

I, Robot is an action-packed thriller with CGI robots, featuring Will Smith and co-stars who create an engaging experience. The film, titled "I, Robot," sees a single man realizing robot threats but humorously suggests it only takes one man to save humanity. It combines action, creativity, and fun, resulting in memorable moments despite its technical elements.

The film's focus on CGI robots and action makes it highly entertaining, with the special effects and production quality adding depth without being overly flashy. Unlike David Attenborough or Simon Schama documentaries, "I, Robot" is more detailed than Alan Titchmarsh's work, though still not as flashy or intricate. However, his attention to its subject—our present-day landscape revealing a past—makes it captivating, particularly when accompanied by a BBC series book.
tinyllama:1.1b: Limited to one man recognizing that robotics pose a threat to humanity, thriller "I, Robot" offers an action-packed film with its extravagant special effects, making it an adequate addition for any action-loving audience. The two-disc version adds more commentaries and additional features, covering all aspects of the production but also highlighting the unique flaws in the special effects. While the additional commentary isn't as detailed as a documentary or a live-action version, it provides insight into the making of the film that fans can enjoy. Though less informative than a BBC series or an Alan Titchmarsh book, the two-disc extra offers enough for a fun and engaging watch.

This movie is based on the 1954 short story by Isaac Asimov and features Will Smith as a detective named Deckard who must stop a group of robots from taking over humanity. The movie was released in 2004 but has recently been re-released in two-disc versions with commentary, making it more accessible to fans of the original film and new viewers alike. Some key aspects of the movie that people appreciate are its thrilling action sequences and impressive visual effects, which have been praised by many critics and audiences alike.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
The DVD review of "I, Robot" features Will Smith alongside numerous CGI robots, classified as a thrilling yet forgettable action film with adequate entertainment value. The one-disc version includes commentaries and a Making Of, while the two-disc set offers additional production diary and post-production features, deviating from typical special effects-focused extras. Despite its shallow nature compared to documentaries, it provides engaging content, particularly in battle scenes.

In contrast, "King Arthur" is a visually impressive but superficial adaptation of the legendary tale. Clive Owen portrays the brooding king, Keira Knightly excels in her role despite the costume, and Ray Winstone adds grit to the cast. The film shines most during its battle scenes, which are well-executed and form the best part of the Making Of extra.

Lastly, "British Isles," a BBC series presented by Alan Titchmarsh, surprises viewers with an engaging exploration of historical Britain. The show, less flashy than documentaries from David Attenborough or Simon Schama, reveals the present-day landscape as it was in the past through revealing sequences. Titchmarsh demonstrates his expertise and has since written a companion book based on his research.
